text: Every time in New York I make it a point to visit Restaurant Saul on Smith Street.
With so many good restaurants on the UWS, I don't need overpriced food, absurdly arrogant wait-staff who don't recognize they work at a glorified diner, clumsy T, and management that doesn't care.
I would not recommend this place to anyone.
Most of the T are very attentive, friendly and quite attractive.
go to any corned indian restaurant, and the little india strip along east 6 st rules supreme!
The service was impeccable and unobtrusive -- the T knows what they are there to do -- to know their menu, present your meal, and attend to your needs.
Definitely try the calamari, any pasta, or even the T.
Be careful of T - they're HUGE.
An awesome organic dog, and a conscious eco friendly T.
I had been a regular due to the consistently good T and ease of getting a table.
get over it!
The T was so-so.
Two complaints- their appetizer selection stinks, it would be nice to get some mozzarella sticks on the T.
They have a delicious banana chocolate dessert, as well as a great T.
Just go to T and order the Red Dragon Roll.
Great T, Poor Service
Fresh T and super tasty.
$6 and there is much tasty T, all of it fresh and continually refilled.
Normally that would be improper, however they were all delicious and my T did not complain.
No free T.
Only drawback - they won't toast your T, and they don't make eggs for the service.
everyone was cheerfully cooperative and helpful.
I liked the atmosphere very much but the T was not worth the price.

We are very particular about sushi and were both please with every choice which included: ceviche mix (special), crab dumplings, assorted sashimi, sushi and T, two types of sake, and the banana tempura.
If you like Sakagura but you feel it's too much, you'd better try Yokocho.
I heard the T was excellent.

A cool T to hang with your friends for a couple of healthy drinks and desserts.
